comment_text.mn41:1.2: This village is possibly connected to the Śālagrāma famed in later years as the origin of the ammonite stones found on the Gaṇḍakī river and worshiped as aniconic forms of Vishnu. Against this theory is that Śālagrāma is too far to the north-east, although in truth we do not know the exact extent of Kosala. The feminine ending of the Pali form suggests that the name means “hall”, but Sanskrit sources trace Śālagrāma to the sal trees that grow abundantly in the Himalayan foothills. | The same framing narrative recurs at MN 60, where the topic of rebirth is also discussed.
comment_text.mn41:4.1: Multiple theories of rebirth are found in Brahmanical texts. For example, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.5 says that rebirth depends on good or bad deeds, but notes the differing opinion that desire is all that matters. Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.10.1–5 describes two paths: forest ascetics go the Brahmā realm, while ritualists go to the moon, from whence those who did good deeds are reborn as human in a good caste, but those who did bad deeds are reborn as outcastes, pigs, or dogs. Those who follow neither path are reborn as small animals or insects.
comment_text.mn41:7.1: This analysis, found frequently in the suttas, became known as the “ten pathways of skilful deeds” (dasakusalakammapatha). It was adopted in the treatment of karma in Manusmṛti 12, where we find a very similar division of “ten characteristics” (daśalakṣaṇa).
comment_text.mn41:8.2: The same description is applied to the notorious serial killer Aṅgulimāla (MN 86:2.1). These definitions dramatically present clear cases of violation and are not intended to be complete or to cover all grey areas. The Vinaya rules analyze these transgressions in detail as they apply to monastic conduct.
comment_text.mn41:8.4: This definition covers a number of sexual transgressions from a male hetero-normative perspective that, with due allowance for social change, would also be considered inappropriate today: when a woman is married or engaged, or illegal sex, or if she is under guardianship, such as for a child or teen. Elsewhere, the texts identify a number of other illicit sexual acts, such as rape (AN 8.84:1.3), underage (Snp 1.6:21.2), incest (AN 5.55), bestiality (Bu Pj 1:6.30), necrophilia (Bu Pj 1:10.13.1), and womanizing or promiscuity in general (AN 8.54:6.2). Notably absent is any criticism of homosexuality, sex outside of marriage, relations with more than two partners, sex work, masturbation, or specific sexual acts.
comment_text.mn41:9.2: Again this is a severe example of lying, essentially perjury.
comment_text.mn41:10.1: These three correspond with the respective defilements greed, hate, and delusion.
comment_text.mn41:10.5: This includes the wrong view that there is no afterlife, but goes beyond that to assert moral nihilism.
comment_text.mn41:15.2: The Buddha is, of course, not recommending this, merely accommodating it. At this point, the ten ways of skillful deeds are both necessary and sufficient for the desired outcome. This changes with the higher realms, where absorption is also required, and the realization of arahantship, which requires the whole noble eightfold path. See note at MN 120:12.12.
comment_text.mn41:18-42.12: Rebirth in this realm and higher is said to depend, not just on the ten ways of doing skillful deeds, but on the development of absorption meditation (DN 13:76.1). Sometimes this is expressed by saying that they are “free from desire” (AN 8.35:4.11, DN 33:3.1.136), a stipulation that is in fact stated in the Chinese parallel to this sutta (SA 1042 at T ii 273a13).
comment_text.mn41:18-42.17: The radiant gods are reborn dependent on the second absorption. The following three classes of gods with “radiance” in their names are subsets of the radiant gods.
comment_text.mn41:18-42.25: The three classes of devas with “beauty” (subha) in their names are reborn due to the third absorption. Some editions have a separate class of “beautiful gods”, of which these three are the subsets, making these follow the same pattern as the “radiant” gods.
comment_text.mn41:18-42.28: This corresponds to the fourth absorption.
comment_text.mn41:18-42.29: These five realms are the Pure Abodes, which are the resort of non-returners only.
comment_text.mn41:18-42.34: These four correespond to the formless attainments.

root_text.mn41:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ yena sālā nāma kosalānaṁ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
root_text.mn41:2.2: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ sālaṁ anuppatto.
root_text.mn41:2.3: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn41:2.4: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’.
root_text.mn41:2.5: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn41:2.6: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ;
root_text.mn41:2.8: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.mn41:3.1: Atha kho sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn41:4.1: “ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu, ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti?
root_text.mn41:4.2: Ko pana, bho gotama, hetu, ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjantī”ti?
root_text.mn41:5.1: “Adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu kho, gahapatayo, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
root_text.mn41:5.2: Dhammacariyāsamacariyāhetu kho, gahapatayo, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjantī”ti.
root_text.mn41:6.1: “Na kho mayaṁ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṁ avibhattassa, vitthārena atthaṁ ājānāma.
root_text.mn41:6.2: Sādhu no bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetu, yathā mayaṁ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṁ avibhattassa, vitthārena atthaṁ ājāneyyāmā”ti.
root_text.mn41:6.3: “Tena hi, gahapatayo, suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn41:6.4: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn41:7.1: “Tividhaṁ kho, gahapatayo, kāyena adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti, catubbidhaṁ vācāya adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti, tividhaṁ manasā adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti.
root_text.mn41:8.1: Kathañca, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ kāyena adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti?
root_text.mn41:8.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti, luddo lohitapāṇi hatappahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.
root_text.mn41:8.3: Adinnādāyī kho pana hoti. Yaṁ taṁ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṁ, gāmagataṁ vā araññagataṁ vā, taṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādātā hoti.
root_text.mn41:8.4: Kāmesumicchācārī kho pana hoti. Yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi, tathārūpāsu cārittaṁ āpajjitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:8.5: Evaṁ kho, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ kāyena adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti.
root_text.mn41:9.1: Kathañca, gahapatayo, catubbidhaṁ vācāya adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti?
root_text.mn41:9.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco musāvādī hoti. Sabhāgato vā parisāgato vā, ñātimajjhagato vā pūgamajjhagato vā rājakulamajjhagato vā, abhinīto sakkhipuṭṭho: ‘ehambho purisa, yaṁ jānāsi taṁ vadehī’ti, so ajānaṁ vā āha: ‘jānāmī’ti, jānaṁ vā āha: na jānāmī’ti, ‘apassaṁ vā āha: ‘passāmī’ti, passaṁ vā āha: ‘na passāmī’ti. Iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:9.3: Pisuṇavāco kho pana hoti. Ito sutvā amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti samaggānaṁ vā bhettā, bhinnānaṁ vā anuppadātā, vaggārāmo vaggarato vagganandī vaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:9.4: Pharusavāco kho pana hoti. Yā sā vācā aṇḍakā kakkasā parakaṭukā parābhisajjanī kodhasāmantā asamādhisaṁvattanikā, tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:9.5: Samphappalāpī kho pana hoti. Akālavādī abhūtavādī anatthavādī adhammavādī avinayavādī. Anidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti akālena anapadesaṁ apariyantavatiṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn41:9.6: Evaṁ kho, gahapatayo, catubbidhaṁ vācāya adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti.
root_text.mn41:10.1: Kathañca, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ manasā adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti?
root_text.mn41:10.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti, yaṁ taṁ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṁ taṁ abhijjhātā hoti: ‘aho vata yaṁ parassa taṁ mamassā’ti.
root_text.mn41:10.3: Byāpannacitto kho pana hoti paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo: ‘ime sattā haññantu vā vajjhantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesun’ti.
root_text.mn41:10.5: ‘natthi dinnaṁ natthi yiṭṭhaṁ natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko natthi paro loko, natthi mātā natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
root_text.mn41:10.6: Evaṁ kho, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ manasā adhammacariyāvisamacariyā hoti.
root_text.mn41:10.7: Evaṁ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu kho, gahapatayo, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
root_text.mn41:11.1: Tividhaṁ kho, gahapatayo, kāyena dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti, catubbidhaṁ vācāya dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti, tividhaṁ manasā dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti.
root_text.mn41:12.1: Kathañca, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ kāyena dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti?
root_text.mn41:12.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn41:12.3: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti. Yaṁ taṁ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṁ, gāmagataṁ vā araññagataṁ vā, taṁ nādinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādātā hoti.
root_text.mn41:12.4: Kāmesumicchācāraṁ pahāya kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti. Yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi, tathārūpāsu na cārittaṁ āpajjitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:12.5: Evaṁ kho, gahapatayo, tividhaṁ kāyena dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti.

root_text.mn41:13.2: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti. Iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā na sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:13.3: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:13.4: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā—tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn41:13.5: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti. Kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn41:13.6: Evaṁ kho, gahapatayo, catubbidhaṁ vācāya dhammacariyāsamacariyā hoti.

root_text.mn41:44.4: Ete mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn41:44.5: Upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṁ gate”ti.

translation_text.mn41:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.
translation_text.mn41:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard,
translation_text.mn41:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn41:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn41:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn41:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased.
translation_text.mn41:2.7: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
translation_text.mn41:2.8: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn41:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn41:4.1: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?
translation_text.mn41:4.2: And what is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”
translation_text.mn41:5.1: “Unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn41:5.2: Principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
translation_text.mn41:6.1: “We don’t understand the detailed meaning of the worthy Gotama’s brief statement.
translation_text.mn41:6.2: Worthy Gotama, please teach us this matter in detail so we can understand the meaning.”
translation_text.mn41:6.3: “Well then, householders, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn41:7.1: “Householders, unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.
translation_text.mn41:8.1: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of body?
translation_text.mn41:8.2: It’s when a certain person kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn41:8.3: They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
translation_text.mn41:8.4: They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
translation_text.mn41:8.5: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body.
translation_text.mn41:9.1: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct fourfold by way of speech?
translation_text.mn41:9.2: It’s when a certain person lies. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
translation_text.mn41:9.3: They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.
translation_text.mn41:9.4: They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion.
translation_text.mn41:9.5: They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless.
translation_text.mn41:9.6: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.
translation_text.mn41:10.1: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of mind?
translation_text.mn41:10.2: It’s when a certain person is covetous. They covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’
translation_text.mn41:10.3: They have ill will and malicious intentions: ‘May these sentient beings be killed, slaughtered, slain, destroyed, or annihilated!’
translation_text.mn41:10.4: They have wrong view. Their perspective is distorted:
translation_text.mn41:10.5: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn41:10.6: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of mind.
translation_text.mn41:10.7: That’s how unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn41:11.1: Householders, principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.
translation_text.mn41:12.1: And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of body?
translation_text.mn41:12.2: It’s when a certain person gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn41:12.3: They give up stealing. They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
translation_text.mn41:12.4: They give up sexual misconduct. They don’t have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They don’t have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
translation_text.mn41:12.5: This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body.
translation_text.mn41:13.1: And how is principled and moral conduct fourfold by way of speech?
translation_text.mn41:13.2: It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
translation_text.mn41:13.3: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn41:13.4: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn41:13.5: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn41:13.6: This is how principled and moral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.
translation_text.mn41:14.1: And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of mind?
translation_text.mn41:14.2: It’s when a certain person is not covetous. They don’t covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’
translation_text.mn41:14.3: They have a kind heart and loving intentions: ‘May these sentient beings live free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy!’
translation_text.mn41:14.4: They have right view, an undistorted perspective:
translation_text.mn41:14.5: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn41:14.6: This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of mind.
translation_text.mn41:14.7: This is how principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn41:15.1: Someone of principled and moral conduct might wish:
translation_text.mn41:15.2: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’
translation_text.mn41:15.3: It’s possible that this might happen.
translation_text.mn41:15.5: Because they have principled and moral conduct.
translation_text.mn41:16-17.1: Someone of principled and moral conduct might wish:
translation_text.mn41:16-17.2: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do brahmins …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.2: the gods of the four great kings …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.10: the gods who love to create …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.11: the gods who control what is created by others …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.12: the gods of the Divinity’s host …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.34: the gods of the dimension of infinite space …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.35: the gods of the dimension of infinite consciousness …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.36: the gods of the dimension of nothingness …
translation_text.mn41:18-42.37: the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
translation_text.mn41:18-42.38: It’s possible that this might happen.
translation_text.mn41:18-42.40: Because they have principled and moral conduct.
translation_text.mn41:43.1: Someone of principled and moral conduct might wish:
translation_text.mn41:43.2: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.mn41:43.3: It’s possible that this might happen.
translation_text.mn41:43.5: Because they have principled and moral conduct.”
translation_text.mn41:44.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn41:44.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn41:44.4: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn41:44.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
